<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init:
```c
int metal_init(const struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	int error = 0;

	if (_metal.common.ref_count++ != 0)
		return 0;

	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));

	_metal.common.log_handler   = params->log_handler;
	_metal.common.log_level     = params->log_level;

	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.bus_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_device_list);

	error = metal_sys_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	++_metal.common.ref_count;
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: here memset is called with the address of the object &_metal and size sizeof(_metal), so the number of bytes written equals the size of that object and will not access beyond its bounds. (A possible violating scenario would be if _metal were actually a pointer and the code misused sizeof(_metal) or an incorrect size, causing memset to write past the allocated object—e.g. using memset(ptr,0,larger_than_allocated_size) on a dynamically allocated struct.)
